questions.question_text: How does a developer create and switch to a new branch called `my-bug-fix` to develop a product fix?

discussion.content:
git branch is used to create branch
Git checkout = the act of switching between different versions of a target entity. The git checkout command operates upon three distinct entities: files, commits, and branches.

Selected Answer: A
A
It is in the book:
git checkout [-b] (branchname or commit)

The -b argument is useful for combining the git branch command with the checkout function and saves a bit of typing by creating the branch and checking it out (switching to it) all at the same time.

A is correct:
The git checkout command accepts a -b argument that acts as a convenience method which will create the new branch and immediately switch to it. 
https://www.atlassian.com/git/tutorials/using-branches/git-checkout

Selected Answer: A
It is correct

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C

https://developer.cisco.com/meraki/api/#!get-organization-insight-monitored-media-servers

Selected Answer: C
POST creates a resource. PUT replaces a resource. PATCH updates a resource.

comments.content: POST is not for updating. POST is for adding.
i got it, in the develpers the GET option has the POST in the sample. My mistake.

discussion.content: POST method is for updating, and the only answer where it is updating something it is B. Shouldn't B the answer. I look at the developers site in CISCO and i have seen the same. Maybe i am wrong, but can someone help me understand this.

Selected Answer: C
Only C makes sense
Agree it should be C - as its using POST Method

Selected Answer: C
I agree with AJ7428. Since it is using "POST" method this creates something new. If it was updating something, it would use "PUT" or "PATCH"

Should be C, as POST method is used.
Correct Answer: C

choices.C: adds a media server to be monitored
choices.D: deletes a media server that is being monitored
choices.B: updates a media server that is being monitored
choices.A: retrieves a media server that is being monitored

questions.question_text:
//IMG//
Refer to the exhibit. Which workflow does the script automate?
Which description of a default gateway is true?

discussion.content: No, it's not, B is correct, D is a switch and the mechanism is different

A. It is a security feature that denies certain traffic. = It’s ACL, wrong 
B. It is a device that receives IP packets that have no explicit next-hop in the routing table. = It’s default gateway because when we do not have a specific route for destination, we will use 0.0.0.0/0 = correct
C. It is a feature that translates between public and private addresses = Its NAT or PAT = wrong 
D. It is a device that receives Layer 2 frames with an unknown destination address = It’s flooding, when we need to send a broadcast to all ports excepting source port for unknown unicast destination = wrong

Selected Answer: B
Answer B

Default Gateway is not equal to Default Route. B is the description for Default Route.
Default gateway is a keyword used on End device(Host).
End device will send frames used the mac address corresponding to the IP address of default gateway setting, when the end device don't know the IP address of destination.
so the answer is D.

comments.content: @Katsuma: Default gateways operate at L3, not L2. A gateway of last resort (or default gw) is a function of routing, L2 has nothing to do with the destination of an IP packet.

discussion.content:
B is the correct answer, the guy that says that D is the correct answer, he is WRONG. check the glossary of CCNA 200-301 ( last version )
: "default gateway/default router On an IP host, the IP address of some router to which the host sends packets when the packet’s destination address is on a subnet other than the local subnet." and the check the explanation of https://networklessons.com/cisco/ccna-routing-switching-icnd1-100-105/what-is-a-default-gateway - When a host wants to reach a destination that is outside of its own network, it has to use a default gateway. We use a router or multilayer switch (that’s a switch that can do routing) as a default gateway.
It's a weird description but B is correct
B is the correct one
B is the correct answer
should be D

comments.content:
default gateway -> Interface configured in the Router, so default Router 
 This is witching ->It is a device that receives Layer 2 frames with an unknown destination address.
Default Gateway works on layer 3, addresses in L2 are mac addresses

choices.D: It is a device that receives Layer 2 frames with an unknown destination address.
choices.B: It is a device that receives IP packets that have no explicit next-hop in the routing table.
choices.C: It is a feature that translates between public and private addresses.
choices.A: It is a security feature that denies certain traffic.

discussion.content: "ssh username@host -p 830" will open up a session via netconf to a device, and you'll receive hello message which contains the capability of the device

Selected Answer: D
Answer D
By default, the NETCONF server on the device runs on TCP port 830 and uses the SSH process for transport. D is the correct answer.
830 tcp port

D is correct . 
 https://developer.cisco.com/docs/ios-xe/#!enabling-netconf-on-ios-xe/addressing-and-ports
830 (TCP) is the port used over SSH

questions.question_text: On which port does NETCONF operate by default?
